abstracts.cdata!:
Despite an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, sustainability is rated as likely, and
            institutional development impacts as modest, given an
            unsatisfactory Bank performance, though satisfactory
            Borrower performance. It is stated that in spite of scope
            reductions in the first (awareness raising) component, the
            project made important contributions to improve the policy
            environment for reproductive health activities. The project
            experience reinforces a number of long-standing lessons.
            These include: avoiding over-commitments for
            "hardware" and infrastructure activities at the
            expense of critical "software" investments in
            training, behavior change, and institutional development;
            the importance of establishing a monitoring and evaluation
            system prior to project launch, including arrangements for
            collecting, and analyzing data; the importance of setting
            realistic targets for development outcomes; and, ensuring
            that scope of planned, and timetable for project activities
            are consistent with borrower implementation capacity. Other
            lessons suggest that: improving demand for, and quality of
            reproductive health services require sustained, long-term
            efforts; in selecting lending instruments, consideration
            should be given to the specific sector objectives, and the
            overall institutional environment of the sector; the Bank,
            government and partners may wish to consider whether
            continuing the nongovernmental organization's financing
            mechanisms - FAP (Fonds d'Appui a la Population) -
            would permit consolidation, and deepening of NGO activities,
            beyond the immediate realm of HIV/AIDS; and, access to, and
            quality of emergency obstetrical services should be improved.
